Enterprise Flask Skill Set Portal: Project Request System

Overview

You can create an enterprise Flask application that serves as a skill set portal where:

  • Admins can post project requests

  • These requests are distributed to relevant users based on skills

  • Users can respond to projects they're interested in

Core Features

1. User Management System

  • Roles: Admin, Manager, Regular User

  • Authentication: Flask-Login or JWT

  • Profile Management: Skills, experience, availability

2. Skill Set Database

  • Skill categories (Programming, Design, Data Science, etc.)

  • Skill levels (Beginner, Intermediate, Expert)

  • Certification tracking

3. Project Request Module

  • Admin interface to create project requests

  • Project details (description, required skills, timeline, budget)

  • Automated matching with user skills

4. Notification System

  • Email/In-app notifications for new projects

  • Reminders for deadlines

  • Status updates

5. Response Management

  • Users can submit interest/availability

  • Team formation tools

  • Status tracking (Pending, Accepted, Rejected)

Technical Implementation

Backend (Flask)

python
Copy
# Example Flask route for project creation
@app.route('/projects/create', methods=['POST'])
@admin_required
def create_project():
    data = request.get_json()
    project = Project(
        title=data['title'],
        description=data['description'],
        required_skills=data['skills'],
        deadline=data['deadline']
    )
    db.session.add(project)
    db.session.commit()
    
    # Notify matching users
    notify_matching_users(project)
    
    return jsonify({"message": "Project created successfully"}), 201

Frontend Options

  • Flask templates with Bootstrap

  • React/Vue.js frontend with Flask API

  • AdminLTE for admin dashboard

Database Models

python
Copy
class User(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), unique=True, nullable=False)
    skills = db.relationship('UserSkill', backref='user', lazy=True)

class Project(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    title = db.Column(db.String(100), nullable=False)
    required_skills = db.Column(db.JSON)  # Stores list of required skills
    responses = db.relationship('ProjectResponse', backref='project', lazy=True)

class ProjectResponse(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('user.id'), nullable=False)
    project_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('project.id'), nullable=False)
    status = db.Column(db.String(20))  # pending, accepted, rejected

Advanced Features to Consider

  1. Skill Matching Algorithm: Automatically suggest projects to users based on their skills

  2. Capacity Planning: Show user availability when assigning projects

  3. Rating System: Allow users to rate projects and admins to rate user performance

  4. Analytics Dashboard: Track project success rates, skill gaps, etc.

  5. Integration with HR Systems: Sync with existing enterprise systems

Deployment Considerations

  • Docker containerization

  • PostgreSQL for production database

  • Redis for caching and queue management

  • Celery for background tasks (notifications, etc.)

Extensions

  1. Mobile App: Companion app for notifications

  2. Chat System: For project discussions

  3. File Sharing: For project documents

  4. Time Tracking: For billable projects

This system would streamline project staffing in enterprises by efficiently matching internal talent with project needs while giving employees visibility into available opportunities.

import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv

load_dotenv()

class Config:
    SECRET_KEY = os.getenv('SECRET_KEY') or 'your-secret-key-here'
    SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI = os.getenv('DATABASE_URL') or 'sqlite:///skill_portal.db'
    SQLALCHEMY_TRACK_MODIFICATIONS = False
    MAIL_SERVER = os.getenv('MAIL_SERVER')
    MAIL_PORT = int(os.getenv('MAIL_PORT') or 25)
    MAIL_USE_TLS = os.getenv('MAIL_USE_TLS') is not None
    MAIL_USERNAME = os.getenv('MAIL_USERNAME')
    MAIL_PASSWORD = os.getenv('MAIL_PASSWORD')
    ADMINS = ['admin@example.com']
    POSTS_PER_PAGE = 20

2. app/init.py

python
Copy
from flask import Flask
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from flask_login import LoginManager
from flask_mail import Mail
from flask_migrate import Migrate
from config import Config

db = SQLAlchemy()
login = LoginManager()
login.login_view = 'auth.login'
mail = Mail()
migrate = Migrate()

def create_app(config_class=Config):
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(config_class)

    db.init_app(app)
    login.init_app(app)
    mail.init_app(app)
    migrate.init_app(app, db)

    from app.auth import bp as auth_bp
    app.register_blueprint(auth_bp, url_prefix='/auth')

    from app.main import bp as main_bp
    app.register_blueprint(main_bp)

    from app.projects import bp as projects_bp
    app.register_blueprint(projects_bp, url_prefix='/projects')

    return app

from app import models

3. app/models.py

python
Copy
from datetime import datetime
from werkzeug.security import generate_password_hash, check_password_hash
from flask_login import UserMixin
from app import db, login

class User(UserMixin, db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    username = db.Column(db.String(64), index=True, unique=True)
    email = db.Column(db.String(120), index=True, unique=True)
    password_hash = db.Column(db.String(128))
    is_admin = db.Column(db.Boolean, default=False)
    last_seen = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)
    skills = db.relationship('UserSkill', backref='user', lazy='dynamic')
    responses = db.relationship('ProjectResponse', backref='user', lazy='dynamic')

    def set_password(self, password):
        self.password_hash = generate_password_hash(password)

    def check_password(self, password):
        return check_password_hash(self.password_hash, password)

class Skill(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = db.Column(db.String(64), unique=True)
    category = db.Column(db.String(64))
    users = db.relationship('UserSkill', backref='skill', lazy='dynamic')

class UserSkill(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('user.id'))
    skill_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('skill.id'))
    level = db.Column(db.String(32))  # Beginner, Intermediate, Expert
    experience = db.Column(db.Integer)  # in months

class Project(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    title = db.Column(db.String(100), nullable=False)
    description = db.Column(db.Text)
    created_by = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('user.id'))
    created_at = db.Column(db.DateTime, index=True, default=datetime.utcnow)
    deadline = db.Column(db.DateTime)
    status = db.Column(db.String(20), default='open')  # open, in_progress, completed
    required_skills = db.relationship('ProjectSkill', backref='project', lazy='dynamic')
    responses = db.relationship('ProjectResponse', backref='project', lazy='dynamic')

class ProjectSkill(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    project_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('project.id'))
    skill_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('skill.id'))
    level_required = db.Column(db.String(32))
    importance = db.Column(db.String(32))  # required, preferred, nice_to_have

class ProjectResponse(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('user.id'))
    project_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('project.id'))
    message = db.Column(db.Text)
    status = db.Column(db.String(20), default='pending')  # pending, accepted, rejected
    responded_at = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)

@login.user_loader
def load_user(id):
    return User.query.get(int(id))

4. app/auth/routes.py

python
Copy
from flask import render_template, flash, redirect, url_for, request
from flask_login import login_user, logout_user, current_user, login_required
from werkzeug.urls import url_parse
from app import db
from app.auth import bp
from app.auth.forms import LoginForm, RegistrationForm
from app.models import User

@bp.route('/login', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def login():
    if current_user.is_authenticated:
        return redirect(url_for('main.index'))
    form = LoginForm()
    if form.validate_on_submit():
        user = User.query.filter_by(username=form.username.data).first()
        if user is None or not user.check_password(form.password.data):
            flash('Invalid username or password')
            return redirect(url_for('auth.login'))
        login_user(user, remember=form.remember_me.data)
        next_page = request.args.get('next')
        if not next_page or url_parse(next_page).netloc != '':
            next_page = url_for('main.index'))
        return redirect(next_page)
    return render_template('auth/login.html', title='Sign In', form=form)

@bp.route('/logout')
def logout():
    logout_user()
    return redirect(url_for('main.index'))

@bp.route('/register', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
def register():
    if current_user.is_authenticated:
        return redirect(url_for('main.index'))
    form = RegistrationForm()
    if form.validate_on_submit():
        user = User(username=form.username.data, email=form.email.data)
        user.set_password(form.password.data)
        db.session.add(user)
        db.session.commit()
        flash('Congratulations, you are now a registered user!')
        return redirect(url_for('auth.login'))
    return render_template('auth/register.html', title='Register', form=form)

5. app/projects/routes.py

python
Copy
from flask import render_template, flash, redirect, url_for, request, current_app
from flask_login import login_required, current_user
from app import db
from app.projects import bp
from app.projects.forms import ProjectForm, ResponseForm
from app.models import Project, ProjectResponse, Skill, UserSkill
from app.email import send_project_notification_email

@bp.route('/create', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
@login_required
def create_project():
    if not current_user.is_admin:
        flash('You do not have permission to create projects')
        return redirect(url_for('main.index'))
    
    form = ProjectForm()
    if form.validate_on_submit():
        project = Project(
            title=form.title.data,
            description=form.description.data,
            created_by=current_user.id,
            deadline=form.deadline.data
        )
        db.session.add(project)
        
        # Add required skills
        for skill_id in form.required_skills.data:
            project_skill = ProjectSkill(
                project_id=project.id,
                skill_id=skill_id,
                level_required=form.skill_level.data,
                importance='required'
            )
            db.session.add(project_skill)
        
        db.session.commit()
        
        # Notify matching users
        notify_matching_users(project)
        
        flash('Your project has been created!')
        return redirect(url_for('projects.view_project', project_id=project.id))
    
    return render_template('projects/create.html', title='Create Project', form=form)

def notify_matching_users(project):
    # Get all skills required for this project
    required_skills = [ps.skill_id for ps in project.required_skills.all()]
    
    # Find users with matching skills
    matching_users = User.query.join(UserSkill).filter(
        UserSkill.skill_id.in_(required_skills),
        UserSkill.level >= project.required_skills.first().level_required
    ).all()
    
    # Send notifications
    for user in matching_users:
        send_project_notification_email(user, project)
        # Could also add in-app notification here

@bp.route('/<int:project_id>', methods=['GET', 'POST'])
@login_required
def view_project(project_id):
    project = Project.query.get_or_404(project_id)
    form = ResponseForm()
    
    if form.validate_on_submit():
        response = ProjectResponse(
            user_id=current_user.id,
            project_id=project.id,
            message=form.message.data
        )
        db.session.add(response)
        db.session.commit()
        flash('Your response has been submitted!')
        return redirect(url_for('projects.view_project', project_id=project.id))
    
    responses = project.responses.order_by(ProjectResponse.responded_at.desc()).all()
    return render_template('projects/view.html', 
                         project=project, 
                         form=form, 
                         responses=responses)

@bp.route('/list')
@login_required
def project_list():
    page = request.args.get('page', 1, type=int)
    projects = Project.query.order_by(Project.created_at.desc()).paginate(
        page, current_app.config['POSTS_PER_PAGE'], False)
    next_url = url_for('projects.project_list', page=projects.next_num) \
        if projects.has_next else None
    prev_url = url_for('projects.project_list', page=projects.prev_num) \
        if projects.has_prev else None
    return render_template('projects/list.html', 
                         title='Projects', 
                         projects=projects.items,
                         next_url=next_url, 
                         prev_url=prev_url)

also with realtionhips aggreagation , composition , inhetence of classes

Here's an enhanced Class Diagram with Relationships (Aggregation, Composition, Inheritance) for your Enterprise Flask Skill Set Portal, with detailed relationship types:

1. Class Diagram with Relationships (composition, aggregation, inheritance)

plantuml
Copy
@startuml ClassDiagramWithRelationships

' ====== Classes ======
class User {
  +id: Integer
  +username: String
  +email: String
  +is_admin: Boolean
  +set_password()
  +check_password()
}

class Admin {
  +create_project()
  +manage_users()
}
User <|-- Admin : Inheritance

class Skill {
  +id: Integer
  +name: String
  +category: String
}

class UserSkill {
  +level: String
  +experience: Integer
}

class Project {
  +title: String
  +description: Text
  +deadline: DateTime
  +status: String
}

class ProjectSkill {
  +level_required: String
  +importance: String
}

class ProjectResponse {
  +message: Text
  +status: String
}

class Notification {
  +content: Text
  +sent_at: DateTime
  +send_email()
}

' ====== Relationships ======
' Composition (strong lifecycle dependency)
Project *-- ProjectSkill : Composition 
Project *-- ProjectResponse : Composition

' Aggregation (weak lifecycle dependency)
User o-- UserSkill : Aggregation
Skill o-- UserSkill : Aggregation
Skill o-- ProjectSkill : Aggregation

' Inheritance
User <|-- Admin

' Associations
User "1" --> "*" Project : Creates
User "1" --> "*" ProjectResponse : Submits
Project "1" --> "*" Notification : Triggers
Notification "1" --> "1" User : Notifies

' ====== Notes ======
note top of User
  **Base class** for all users.
  Admins inherit additional privileges.
end note

note right of Project
  **Composition** with ProjectSkill:
  - Skills cannot exist without a Project
  - Deleted Project → Skills deleted
end note

@enduml

Key Relationship Explanations

1. Composition (🟦 Strong Lifecycle)

  • Project *-- ProjectSkill

    • Project OWNS its required skills

    • If Project is deleted, all its ProjectSkill entries are deleted

  • Project *-- ProjectResponse

    • Project OWNS responses

    • Deleting Project cascades to responses

2. Aggregation (🟨 Weak Lifecycle)

  • User o-- UserSkill

    • User HAS-A skills (but skills can exist independently)

    • Deleting User doesn’t delete Skill table

  • Skill o-- UserSkill

    • Skill can be linked to multiple users

3. Inheritance (🟪 Generalization)

  • User <|-- Admin

    • Admin IS-A specialized User with extra privileges

4. Plain Associations (➜)

  • User --> Project

    • User creates Projects (no lifecycle dependency)

  • Project --> Notification

    • Project triggers notifications

2. Sequence Diagram (with Relationship Emphasis)

plantuml
Copy
@startuml ProjectCreationWithRelationships

actor Admin
participant "Web UI" as UI
participant "ProjectController" as Controller
database "ProjectDB" as ProjectDB
database "SkillDB" as SkillDB

Admin -> UI: Create Project (Form)
UI -> Controller: POST /projects (title, skills)
Controller -> ProjectDB: **new Project()** (Composition)
ProjectDB -> SkillDB: **add ProjectSkill()** (Aggregation)
SkillDB --> ProjectDB: Skills linked
ProjectDB --> Controller: Project created
Controller --> UI: Success
UI --> Admin: Confirmation

@enduml

3. Component Diagram (Relationships Highlighted)

plantuml
Copy
@startuml ComponentRelationships

component "UserService" as User {
  component "UserDB" as UserDB
}

component "ProjectService" as Project {
  component "ProjectDB" as ProjectDB
  component "SkillDB" as SkillDB
}

component "NotificationService" as Notify

UserDB o-- SkillDB : Aggregation (UserSkills)
ProjectDB *-- SkillDB : Composition (ProjectSkills)
Project --> Notify : Association (Trigger)

@enduml

Key Takeaways

  1. Composition (🟦)

    • Strong lifecycle binding (parent dies → children die)

    • Example: Project and its ProjectSkills

  2. Aggregation (🟨)

    • Weak "has-a" relationship (independent lifecycles)

    • Example: Skill can exist without User

  3. Inheritance (🟪)

    • Admin extends User (specialization)

  4. Associations (➜)

    • Runtime interactions without lifecycle dependency

also if there are issues how to restart that workflow ... incident management , monitoring on dashboard , so to check who accepted project who request on dashboard

Here's a comprehensive enhancement to your system design with incident management, monitoring dashboards, and workflow recovery:

1. Incident Management & Workflow Restart System

PlantUML: Incident Recovery Workflow

plantuml
Copy
@startuml IncidentRecoveryWorkflow

state "Project Workflow" as workflow {
  [*] --> Draft
  Draft --> Open : Publish
  Open --> InProgress : Team Formed
  InProgress --> Completed : Delivery
}

state "Error Handling" as error {
  [*] --> ErrorDetected
  ErrorDetected --> RootCauseAnalysis
  RootCauseAnalysis --> ManualIntervention
  ManualIntervention --> WorkflowRestart
  WorkflowRestated --> [*]
}

workflow --> error : On Failure
error --> workflow : Restart from last stable state

@enduml

Implementation Code

python
Copy
# app/incidents/routes.py
from flask import Blueprint, jsonify
from app.models import Project, WorkflowLog
from app import db

bp = Blueprint('incidents', __name__)

@bp.route('/projects/<int:project_id>/restart', methods=['POST'])
@admin_required
def restart_workflow(project_id):
    project = Project.query.get_or_404(project_id)
    last_stable = WorkflowLog.query.filter_by(
        project_id=project_id,
        is_stable=True
    ).order_by(WorkflowLog.timestamp.desc()).first()
    
    if last_stable:
        project.status = last_stable.state
        db.session.commit()
        return jsonify({"message": f"Workflow restarted from {last_stable.state}"}), 200
    return jsonify({"error": "No recovery point found"}), 404

# app/models.py
class AuditLog(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('user.id'))
    action = db.Column(db.String(50))  # 'project_create', 'response_accept'
    target_id = db.Column(db.Integer)  # Project/User ID
    timestamp = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)
    ip_address = db.Column(db.String(45))
    
class WorkflowLog(db.Model):
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    project_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('project.id'))
    state = db.Column(db.String(20))  # 'Draft', 'InProgress'
    is_stable = db.Column(db.Boolean, default=True)
    error = db.Column(db.Text)
    timestamp = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)

4. Real-time Monitoring API Endpoints

python
Copy
# app/monitoring/routes.py
@bp.route('/metrics/projects')
def project_metrics():
    data = {
        'status_counts': dict(db.session.query(
            Project.status, 
            func.count(Project.id)
        ).group_by(Project.status).all()),
        'acceptance_rate': db.session.query(
            func.avg(case(
                (ProjectResponse.status == 'accepted', 1),
                else_=0
            ))
        ).scalar()
    }
    return jsonify(data)

@bp.route('/audit/<int:project_id>')
def project_audit_log(project_id):
    logs = AuditLog.query.filter_by(
        target_id=project_id
    ).order_by(AuditLog.timestamp.desc()).limit(100).all()
    return jsonify([log.to_dict() for log in logs])

2. Modified Files for New Requirements

app/extensions.py (New File)

python
Copy
from flask_sqlalchemy import SQLAlchemy
from flask_login import LoginManager
from flask_migrate import Migrate
from flask_mail import Mail
from flask_celery import Celery
from elasticsearch import Elasticsearch

db = SQLAlchemy()
login = LoginManager()
migrate = Migrate()
mail = Mail()
celery = Celery()
es = Elasticsearch()

def init_extensions(app):
    db.init_app(app)
    login.init_app(app)
    migrate.init_app(app, db)
    mail.init_app(app)
    celery.conf.update(app.config)
    es.init_app(app)

app/__init__.py (Modified)

python
Copy
from flask import Flask
from config import Config
from .extensions import init_extensions, db, login, migrate, mail, celery, es

def create_app(config_class=Config):
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(config_class)
    
    # Initialize extensions
    init_extensions(app)
    
    # Register blueprints
    from .auth import bp as auth_bp
    from .projects import bp as projects_bp
    from .incidents import bp as incidents_bp
    from .monitoring import bp as monitoring_bp
    
    app.register_blueprint(auth_bp, url_prefix='/auth')
    app.register_blueprint(projects_bp, url_prefix='/projects')
    app.register_blueprint(incidents_bp, url_prefix='/incidents')
    app.register_blueprint(monitoring_bp, url_prefix='/monitoring')
    
    # Initialize celery
    celery.conf.update(app.config)
    
    return app

app/models.py (Modified)

python
Copy
from datetime import datetime
from .extensions import db

# ... (existing models)

class AuditLog(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'audit_logs'
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    user_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('users.id'))
    action = db.Column(db.String(50), nullable=False)
    target_type = db.Column(db.String(30))  # 'project', 'response'
    target_id = db.Column(db.Integer))  # ID of the target entity
    metadata = db.Column(db.JSON))  # Additional context
    created_at = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)

class WorkflowLog(db.Model):
    __tablename__ = 'workflow_logs'
    id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
    project_id = db.Column(db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('projects.id'))
    from_state = db.Column(db.String(30))
    to_state = db.Column(db.String(30))
    is_stable = db.Column(db.Boolean, default=True)
    error = db.Column(db.Text)
    created_at = db.Column(db.DateTime, default=datetime.utcnow)

# Add relationship to Project model
class Project(db.Model):
    # ... existing fields ...
    workflow_logs = db.relationship('WorkflowLog', backref='project', lazy='dynamic')

app/projects/utils.py (Modified)

python
Copy
from ..extensions import db
from ..models import WorkflowLog, AuditLog

def log_workflow_change(project, from_state, to_state, user_id=None, error=None):
    log = WorkflowLog(
        project_id=project.id,
        from_state=from_state,
        to_state=to_state,
        error=error,
        is_stable=(error is None)
    )
    db.session.add(log)
    
    if user_id:
        audit = AuditLog(
            user_id=user_id,
            action=f'project_state_change',
            target_type='project',
            target_id=project.id,
            metadata={
                'from': from_state,
                'to': to_state,
                'error': bool(error)
            }
        )
        db.session.add(audit)
    
    db.session.commit()

6. Maintenance Scripts

Create scripts/maintenance.sh:

bash
Copy
#!/bin/bash

# Daily backup
pg_dump -U portal_user skill_portal > /backups/skill_portal_$(date +%F).sql

# Log rotation
find /var/log/skillportal -name "*.log" -mtime +30 -delete

# Monitor disk space
df -h | grep -vE '^Filesystem|tmpfs|cdrom' | awk '{ print $5 " " $1 }' | while read output;
do
  used=$(echo $output | awk '{print $1}' | cut -d'%' -f1)
  if [ $used -gt 80 ]; then
    echo "Running out of space: $output" | mail -s "Disk Alert" admin@example.com
  fi
done

# app/monitoring/routes.py
from flask import Response

@bp.route('/dashboard/stream')
def dashboard_stream():
    def event_stream():
        while True:
            data = get_realtime_updates()  # Your function
            yield f"data: {data}\n\n"
            time.sleep(10)  # Update every 10 seconds
            
    return Response(event_stream(), mimetype="text/event-stream")

# app/forms.py
from flask_wtf import FlaskForm
from wtforms import FormField, FieldList
from wtforms.validators import DataRequired

class SkillRequirementForm(FlaskForm):
    skill = StringField('Skill', validators=[DataRequired()])
    level = SelectField('Level', choices=[('basic', 'Basic'), ('expert', 'Expert')])

class ProjectRequestForm(FlaskForm):
    basic_info = FormField(BasicInfoForm)
    required_skills = FieldList(FormField(SkillRequirementForm), min_entries=1)
    attachments = MultipleFileField('Supporting Files')

# config.py
import os
from pathlib import Path

UPLOAD_FOLDER = Path.home() / 'skillportal_uploads'
os.makedirs(UPLOAD_FOLDER, exist_ok=True)

class Config:
    MAX_CONTENT_LENGTH = 16 * 1024 * 1024  # 16MB limit
    ALLOWED_EXTENSIONS = {'pdf', 'docx', 'png'}

Secure Upload Handler

python
Copy
# app/utils/uploads.py
from werkzeug.utils import secure_filename
from flask import current_app

def handle_upload(files):
    saved_paths = []
    for file in files:
        if file and allowed_file(file.filename):
            filename = secure_filename(file.filename)
            save_path = current_app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'] / filename
            file.save(save_path)
            saved_paths.append(str(save_path))
    return saved_paths

3. Lightweight Gantt Chart

Server-Side Data Prep

python
Copy
# app/dashboard/utils.py
from textwrap import dedent

def generate_gantt(projects):
    chart = ["Project Timeline:\n"]
    for p in projects:
        bar = '█' * int(p.duration_days / 2)
        chart.append(f"{p.title[:15].ljust(15)}: {bar} ({p.duration_days}d)")
    return dedent("\n".join(chart))

5. Home-VM Optimized Features

A. Auto-Clean Uploads

python
Copy
# app/tasks.py
from pathlib import Path

@celery.task
def clean_uploads():
    upload_dir = Path(current_app.config['UPLOAD_FOLDER'])
    for file in upload_dir.glob('*'):
        if file.stat().st_mtime < (time.time() - 30 * 86400):  # 30 days
            file.unlink()

thanks , also did we generate flask project with software design patterns and also if we can generate all the logs so can traced and tracked like splunk

Here's a production-ready Flask setup with design patterns and Splunk-compatible logging that you can implement on your Ubuntu VM:

1. Key Design Patterns Implemented

A. Repository Pattern (Data Access)

python
Copy
# app/repositories/project_repo.py
class ProjectRepository:
    def __init__(self, db):
        self.db = db

    def get_by_status(self, status):
        return Project.query.filter_by(status=status).all()

    def add_response(self, project_id, user_id, message):
        response = ProjectResponse(
            project_id=project_id,
            user_id=user_id,
            message=message
        )
        self.db.session.add(response)
        return response

B. Strategy Pattern (Notification Service)

python
Copy
# app/services/notification_strategy.py
class NotificationStrategy(ABC):
    @abstractmethod
    def send(self, user, message):
        pass

class EmailNotification(NotificationStrategy):
    def send(self, user, message):
        # Email implementation
        pass

class SlackNotification(NotificationStrategy):
    def send(self, user, message):
        # Slack webhook
        pass

class NotificationContext:
    def __init__(self, strategy):
        self._strategy = strategy

    def execute(self, user, message):
        self._strategy.send(user, message)

2. Splunk-Compatible Logging Setup

A. Structured Logging Configuration

python
Copy
# app/logging.py
import logging
from pythonjsonlogger import jsonlogger

def setup_logging():
    logger = logging.getLogger()
    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)

    # Splunk-friendly JSON format
    formatter = jsonlogger.JsonFormatter(
        '%(asctime)s %(levelname)s %(name)s %(message)s'
    )

    # File handler (rotate daily)
    file_handler = logging.handlers.TimedRotatingFileHandler(
        '/var/log/skillportal/app.log',
        when='midnight',
        backupCount=7
    )
    file_handler.setFormatter(formatter)

    # Syslog handler (for Splunk forwarder)
    syslog_handler = logging.handlers.SysLogHandler(
        address=('localhost', 514)
    )
    syslog_handler.setFormatter(formatter)

    logger.addHandler(file_handler)
    logger.addHandler(syslog_handler)

B. Logging Decorators

python
Copy
# app/decorators.py
def log_endpoint(func):
    @wraps(func)
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        logger.info(
            "Endpoint accessed",
            extra={
                "endpoint": request.endpoint,
                "method": request.method,
                "user": current_user.id if current_user.is_authenticated else None,
                "params": request.args.to_dict()
            }
        )
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
    return wrapper

3. Centralized Logging Architecture

Log Flow Diagram (PlantUML)

plantuml
Copy
@startuml
component "Flask App" as app {
  [Application Logs]
}

component "Rsyslog" as rsyslog {
  [Log Forwarder]
}

component "Splunk" as splunk {
  [Indexer]
  [Search Head]
}

app -> rsyslog : UDP 514 (syslog)
rsyslog -> splunk : TCP 9997 (HEC)
@enduml

  string="%TIMESTAMP% %HOSTNAME% %syslogtag% %msg%\n"
)

local7.* /var/log/skillportal/app.log;SkillPortalFormat
*.* @your.splunk.server:514

# app/logging.py (Essential logging setup)
import logging
from pythonjsonlogger import jsonlogger

def get_logger(name):
    logger = logging.getLogger(name)
    handler = logging.FileHandler('/var/log/skillportal/app.log')
    formatter = jsonlogger.JsonFormatter('%(asctime)s %(levelname)s %(name)s %(message)s')
    handler.setFormatter(formatter)
    logger.addHandler(handler)
    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)
    return logger

Here's the complete integrated structure with logging, tracing, and design patterns baked into your Flask project:

Project Structure with Full Observability

Copy
skill_portal/
├── app/
│   ├── __init__.py                 # App factory with logging init
│   ├── extensions.py               # Design pattern integrations
│   ├── logging/                    # Observability core
│   │   ├── __init__.py            # Logger setup
│   │   ├── middleware.py          # Request tracing
│   │   ├── filters.py             # Custom log filters
│   │   └── handlers.py            # Splunk/File handlers
│   ├── models.py                   # DB models with __repr__
│   ├── repositories/               # Repository pattern
│   │   ├── __init__.py
│   │   ├── project_repo.py        # Project DB operations
│   │   └── user_repo.py           # User DB operations

1. app/__init__.py (Integrated Setup)

python
Copy
from flask import Flask
from .logging import init_logging, request_tracer
from .extensions import db, cache

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object('config.Config')
    
    # Initialize extensions
    db.init_app(app)
    cache.init_app(app)
    
    # Initialize logging and tracing
    init_logging(app)
    app.before_request(request_tracer)  # Attach request IDs
    
    # Register blueprints
    from .blueprints import projects, auth
    app.register_blueprint(projects.bp)
    app.register_blueprint(auth.bp)
    
    return app

2. app/logging/__init__.py (Core Logging)

python
Copy
import logging
from pythonjsonlogger import jsonlogger
from .handlers import SplunkHandler, FileHandler
from .filters import RequestFilter

def init_logging(app):
    logger = logging.getLogger()
    logger.setLevel(app.config['LOG_LEVEL'])
    
    # JSON formatter with Splunk-compatible format
    formatter = jsonlogger.JsonFormatter(
        '%(asctime)s %(levelname)s %(name)s %(request_id)s %(message)s'
    )
    
    # Handlers
    file_handler = FileHandler(filename=app.config['LOG_FILE'])
    splunk_handler = SplunkHandler(url=app.config['SPLUNK_HEC_URL'])
    
    for handler in [file_handler, splunk_handler]:
        handler.addFilter(RequestFilter())
        handler.setFormatter(formatter)
        logger.addHandler(handler)
    
    # Silence noisy loggers
    for name in ['werkzeug', 'sqlalchemy']:
        logging.getLogger(name).setLevel(logging.WARNING)

3. app/logging/middleware.py (Request Tracing)

python
Copy
import uuid
from flask import g, request

def request_tracer():
    """Attach request ID to all logs"""
    g.request_id = request.headers.get('X-Request-ID', str(uuid.uuid4()))
    g.start_time = time.time()

def after_request_tracing(response):
    """Log request completion"""
    duration = (time.time() - g.start_time) * 1000  # in ms
    logging.getLogger('http').info(
        "Request completed",
        extra={
            'method': request.method,
            'path': request.path,
            'status': response.status_code,
            'duration_ms': duration,
            'ip': request.remote_addr
        }
    )
    response.headers['X-Request-ID'] = g.request_id
    return response

4. app/repositories/project_repo.py (Pattern Implementation)

python

from ..extensions import db
from ..logging import get_logger

logger = get_logger(__name__)

class ProjectRepository:
    def __init__(self):
        self.session = db.session

    def get_by_id(self, project_id):
        try:
            project = self.session.query(Project).get(project_id)
            logger.debug("Fetched project", extra={'project_id': project_id})
            return project
        except Exception as e:
            logger.error("Project fetch failed", 
                        extra={'error': str(e), 'project_id': project_id})
            raise

5. app/services/tracing.py (OpenTelemetry Integration)

python
Copy
from opentelemetry import trace
from opentelemetry.sdk.trace import TracerProvider
from opentelemetry.sdk.resources import Resource
from opentelemetry.exporter.otlp.proto.grpc.trace_exporter import OTLPSpanExporter

def init_tracing(app):
    trace.set_tracer_provider(
        TracerProvider(
            resource=Resource.create({"service.name": "skill-portal"})
        )
    )
    
    if app.config['ENABLE_TRACING']:
        trace.get_tracer_provider().add_span_processor(
            BatchSpanProcessor(OTLPSpanExporter(
                endpoint=app.config['OTLP_ENDPOINT']
            ))
        )

    # Tracing
    ENABLE_TRACING = os.getenv('ENABLE_TRACING', False)
    OTLP_ENDPOINT = os.getenv('OTLP_ENDPOINT', 'http://localhost:4317')

Key Integrated Files

1. app/__init__.py (Unified App Factory)

python
Copy
from flask import Flask
from .extensions import db, cache
from .logging import init_logging, setup_request_tracing
from .services.tracing import init_tracing

def create_app(config_class='config.Config'):
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object(config_class)

    # Initialize extensions
    db.init_app(app)
    cache.init_app(app)
    
    # Setup observability
    init_logging(app)
    setup_request_tracing(app)
    if app.config['ENABLE_TRACING']:
        init_tracing(app)

    # Register blueprints
    from .routes import auth, projects, admin
    app.register_blueprint(auth.bp)
    app.register_blueprint(projects.bp)
    app.register_blueprint(admin.bp)

    # Add error handling
    register_error_handlers(app)

    return app

def register_error_handlers(app):
    @app.errorhandler(404)
    def handle_404(e):
        app.logger.warning("404 encountered", extra={"path": request.path})
        return jsonify(error="Not found"), 404

    @app.errorhandler(500)
    def handle_500(e):
        app.logger.error("Server error", exc_info=True)
        return jsonify(error="Internal error"), 500

3. app/logging/__init__.py (Centralized Logging)

python
Copy
import logging
from pythonjsonlogger import jsonlogger
from .handlers import SplunkHandler, FileHandler

def init_logging(app):
    """Configure application-wide logging"""
    logger = logging.getLogger()
    logger.setLevel(app.config['LOG_LEVEL'])

    formatter = jsonlogger.JsonFormatter(
        '%(asctime)s %(levelname)s %(name)s %(request_id)s %(message)s'
    )

    # Production handlers
    if app.config['ENV'] == 'production':
        handlers = [
            SplunkHandler(app.config['SPLUNK_HEC_URL']),
            FileHandler(app.config['LOG_FILE'])
        ]
    else:
        handlers = [logging.StreamHandler()]

    for handler in handlers:
        handler.setFormatter(formatter)
        logger.addHandler(handler)

def setup_request_tracing(app):
    """Attach request-scoped identifiers"""
    @app.before_request
    def assign_request_id():
        from flask import g
        g.request_id = request.headers.get('X-Request-ID', str(uuid.uuid4()))
        g.start_time = time.time()

    @app.after_request
    def log_request(response):
        duration = (time.time() - g.start_time) * 1000
        app.logger.info(
            "Request completed",
            extra={
                "method": request.method,
                "path": request.path,
                "status": response.status_code,
                "duration_ms": duration,
                "ip": request.remote_addr
            }
        )
        response.headers['X-Request-ID'] = g.request_id
        return response

4. app/routes/projects.py (Blueprint Example)

python
Copy
from flask import Blueprint, request
from ..extensions import get_project_repository
from ..utils.decorators import logged_route

bp = Blueprint('projects', __name__)
repo = get_project_repository()

@bp.route('/projects', methods=['GET'])
@logged_route
def list_projects():
    try:
        projects = repo.get_all()
        return jsonify([p.to_dict() for p in projects])
    except Exception as e:
        current_app.logger.error("Project list failed", exc_info=True)
        raise

@bp.route('/projects', methods=['POST'])
@logged_route
def create_project():
    data = request.get_json()
    project = repo.create(data)
    return jsonify(project.to_dict()), 201

5. app/utils/decorators.py (Route Decorators)

python
Copy
from functools import wraps
from flask import request, current_app

def logged_route(f):
    @wraps(f)
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        current_app.logger.info(
            "Route entered",
            extra={
                "route": request.endpoint,
                "params": request.args.to_dict(),
                "payload": request.get_json(silent=True)
            }
        )
        return f(*args, **kwargs)
    return wrapper

1. app/__init__.py

python
Copy
from flask import Flask
from .core.logging import init_logging
from .extensions import db, cache

def create_app():
    app = Flask(__name__)
    app.config.from_object('app.config.Config')
    
    # Initialize extensions
    db.init_app(app)
    cache.init_app(app)
    
    # Setup infrastructure
    init_logging(app)
    register_blueprints(app)
    register_error_handlers(app)
    
    return app

def register_blueprints(app):
    from .api.v1 import projects, auth
    app.register_blueprint(projects.bp, url_prefix='/v1')
    app.register_blueprint(auth.bp, url_prefix='/v1')

2. app/core/logging/__init__.py

python
Copy
import logging
from pythonjsonlogger import jsonlogger

def init_logging(app):
    handler = logging.FileHandler(app.config['LOG_FILE'])
    formatter = jsonlogger.JsonFormatter(
        '%(asctime)s %(levelname)s %(name)s %(request_id)s %(message)s'
    )
    handler.setFormatter(formatter)
    app.logger.addHandler(handler)
    app.logger.setLevel(app.config['LOG_LEVEL'])

3. app/domain/repositories/project_repo.py

python
Copy
from ..models.project import Project
from ..extensions import db

class ProjectRepository:
    def __init__(self):
        self.session = db.session

    def get_by_id(self, project_id):
        return self.session.query(Project).get(project_id)
    
    def create(self, data):
        project = Project(**data)
        self.session.add(project)
        self.session.commit()
        return project

how to save setting.json

Here's how to save your VS Code settings for the Flask project, with proper version control integration:

Method 1: Direct Configuration (Recommended)

  1. Open VS Code Settings:

    • Windows/Linux: Ctrl + ,

    • Mac: Cmd + ,

  2. Access Settings JSON:

    • Click the {} icon in the top-right corner of the settings tab

  3. Paste the Configuration:

    json
    Copy
    {
  "python.linting.enabled": true,
  "python.linting.pylintEnabled": true,
  "python.formatting.provider": "black",
  "python.analysis.typeCheckingMode": "strict",
  "logViewer.autoStart": true,
  "[python]": {
    "editor.defaultFormatter": "ms-python.python"
  }
}

  4. Save Automatically:

    • Changes are saved instantly to:

      • Windows: %APPDATA%\Code\User\settings.json

      • Mac: $HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User/settings.json

      • Linux: $HOME/.config/Code/User/settings.json

Method 2: Project-Specific Settings

  1. Create Workspace Settings:

    bash
    Copy
    mkdir -p .vscode && touch .vscode/settings.json

  2. Add Project-Specific Config:

    json
    Copy
    {
  "python.pythonPath": "venv/bin/python",
  "python.linting.pylintArgs": [
    "--load-plugins=pylint_flask_sqlalchemy"
  ],
  "files.exclude": {
    "**/__pycache__": true,
    "**/.pytest_cache": true
  }
}

  3. Commit to Git:

    bash
    Copy
    echo ".vscode/settings.json" >> .gitignore  # Or include it for team sharing
git add .vscode/settings.json

Method 3: Sync Across Devices

  1. Enable Settings Sync:

    • Click the gear icon → "Turn on Settings Sync"

    • Choose which settings to sync (extensions, keybindings, etc.)

  2. Manual Backup:

    bash
    Copy
    # Copy settings file
cp "$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User/settings.json" ./vscode-backup/

Key Settings for Flask Projects

SettingRecommended ValuePurpose
python.analysis.extraPaths["app"]Better import resolution
python.testing.pytestArgs["tests"]Test discovery
python.formatting.blackArgs["--line-length=88"]Consistent formatting
debug.console.wordWraptrueReadable debug output

Verification Steps

  1. Check active settings:

    bash
    Copy
    code --list-extensions | grep -E 'python|flask'

  2. Validate settings:

    bash
    Copy
    cat .vscode/settings.json | python -m json.tool

  3. Test in action:

    • Open a Flask route file

    • Check for proper:

      • Autocomplete (Pylance)

      • Linting (pylint)

      • Formatting (Black)

Troubleshooting

If settings don't apply:

  1. Reload VS Code (Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + P → "Reload Window")

  2. Check for conflicts in:

    bash
    Copy
    diff <(code --user-data-dir /tmp/empty --list-extensions) <(code --list-extensions)

  3. Reset corrupted settings:

    bash
    Copy
    rm "$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User/settings.json"

Best Practices

  1. Team Sharing: Include .vscode/settings.json in Git for consistent environments

  2. Sensitive Data: Never store paths with usernames/hostnames

  3. Extension Recommendations: Create .vscode/extensions.json:

    json
    Copy
    {
  "recommendations": [
    "ms-python.python",
    "cstrap.flask-snippets"
  ]
}

You're absolutely right to catch that contradiction! Let me clarify the correct workflow for handling VS Code settings in Git:

Correct Approach for Version-Controlled Settings

1. For Team Projects (Share Settings)

bash
Copy
# 1. Create .vscode/ directory with settings
mkdir -p .vscode && cat > .vscode/settings.json << 'EOL'
{
  "python.pythonPath": "venv/bin/python",
  "python.linting.enabled": true,
  "files.exclude": {
    "**/__pycache__": true,
    "**/.pytest_cache": true
  }
}
EOL

# 2. Add to Git (shared with team)
git add .vscode/settings.json
git commit -m "Add shared VS Code settings"

# 3. Create .gitignore for personal files
echo ".vscode/*.local" >> .gitignore
echo "venv/" >> .gitignore

2. For Personal Projects (Ignore All)

bash
Copy
# Add entire .vscode to gitignore
echo ".vscode/" >> .gitignore
git add .gitignore
git commit -m "Ignore IDE settings"

When to Add vs Ignore

ScenarioActionFiles to Include/Exclude
Team collaborationAdd to Git.vscode/settings.json, .vscode/extensions.json
Personal projectIgnoreEntire .vscode/ directory
Mixed environmentPartial addShare only critical settings:
.vscode/settings.json (no paths)

Best Practice Structure

Copy
project-root/
├── .vscode/
│   ├── settings.json          # Shared settings (in Git)
│   ├── settings.local.json    # Personal overrides (in .gitignore)
│   └── extensions.json        # Recommended extensions (in Git)
├── .gitignore                # Contains "/.vscode/settings.local.json"
└── ...

git not found on ubntu

If you're getting a git not found error on Ubuntu, it means Git isn't installed. Here's how to install and configure Git properly:

1. Install Git on Ubuntu

bash
Copy
# Update package list
sudo apt update

# Install Git
sudo apt install git -y

# Verify installation
git --version

You should see output like: git version 2.34.1

2. Basic Git Configuration

bash
Copy
# Set your identity (use your actual name/email)
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

# Enable colorful output
git config --global color.ui auto

# Verify configuration
git config --list

3. Initialize Git in Your Project

bash
Copy
# Navigate to your project
cd ~/skill_portal

# Initialize repository
git init

# Stage all files
git add .

# Make first commit
git commit -m "Initial project structure"

4. Fix Common Issues

If you get sudo: apt: command not found

Try these alternatives:

bash
Copy
# For older Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install git

# For Fedora/RHEL
sudo dnf install git

# For minimal installations
sudo snap install git

If you see E: Unable to locate package git

Update your package sources first:

bash
Copy
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y

5. Set Up Remote Repository (GitHub/GitLab)

bash
Copy
# Create new repo on GitHub/GitLab, then:
git remote add origin https://github.com/yourusername/skill_portal.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

6. Essential Git Commands Cheat Sheet

CommandDescription
git statusCheck changed files
git add <file>Stage specific file
git commit -m "message"Commit changes
git logView commit history
git pullFetch + merge changes
git pushUpload your commits

7. Verify Git is Working

bash
Copy
# Check if Git recognizes your project
git status

# Should show something like:
# On branch main
# nothing to commit, working tree clean

Troubleshooting

If you still get git: command not found after installation

  1. Refresh your shell:

    bash
    Copy
    source ~/.bashrc

  2. Check Git's install location:

    bash
    Copy
    which git

    Should return: /usr/bin/git

  3. Manually add to PATH (if needed):

    bash
    Copy
    echo 'export PATH=$PATH:/usr/bin/git' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

Next Steps

  1. Install GUI tools (optional):

    bash
    Copy
    sudo apt install gitk git-gui -y

  2. Set up SSH keys for secure pushing:

    bash
    Copy
    ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@example.com"
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

    Then add to GitHub/GitLab

  3. Install Git LFS for large files (if needed):

    bash
    Copy
    sudo apt install git-lfs -y
git lfs install

https://docs.github.com/get-started/getting-started-with-git/about-remote-repositories#cloning-with-https-urls

Here's a concise guide to working with remote repositories using HTTPS URLs in your Ubuntu Flask project, integrating with the GitHub documentation you referenced:

1. Clone Your Repository (HTTPS)

bash
Copy
# Navigate to your desired directory
cd ~/projects

# Clone using HTTPS URL (from GitHub repo page)
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/skill_portal.git

# Enter the project directory
cd skill_portal

2. Configure Git Credential Helper (Avoid Repeated Logins)

bash
Copy
# Cache your GitHub credentials for 1 hour (default)
git config --global credential.helper cache

# Or store them indefinitely (secure storage)
git config --global credential.helper store

3. Connect Existing Local Project to GitHub

bash
Copy
# Initialize Git if not done already
git init

# Add all files
git add .

# Make initial commit
git commit -m "Initial commit"

# Create a new repo on GitHub (no README/license)
# Then connect local repo to remote
git remote add origin https://github.com/yourusername/skill_portal.git

# Verify remote
git remote -v
# Should show:
# origin  https://github.com/yourusername/skill_portal.git (fetch)
# origin  https://github.com/yourusername/skill_portal.git (push)

# Push to main branch
git push -u origin main

4. Handling Authentication

Personal Access Token (PAT)

Since GitHub deprecated password authentication:

  1. Create a PAT with repo permissions

  2. Use it as your password when prompted:

    Copy
    Username: yourgithubusername
Password: ghp_yourPAThere

SSH Alternative (Recommended)

bash
Copy
# Generate SSH key (if you haven't)
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your.email@example.com"

# Add to ssh-agent
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

# Copy public key
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
# Add to GitHub: Settings → SSH and GPG keys

# Change remote URL to SSH
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:yourusername/skill_portal.git

5. Common HTTPS Workflow

bash
Copy
# Pull latest changes
git pull origin main

# Make changes, then:
git add .
git commit -m "Your message"
git push origin main

6. Troubleshooting HTTPS Issues

Authentication Errors

bash
Copy
# Reset cached credentials
git credential-cache exit

# On Ubuntu 22.04+ use the libsecret helper:
sudo apt-get install libsecret-1-0 libsecret-1-dev
git config --global credential.helper /usr/share/doc/git/contrib/credential/libsecret/git-credential-libsecret

SSL Certificate Problems

bash
Copy
# Temporarily disable SSL verification (not recommended)
git config --global http.sslVerify false

# Better solution: Update CA certificates
sudo apt-get install --reinstall ca-certificates

Key Differences: HTTPS vs SSH

FeatureHTTPSSSH
AuthenticationPAT requiredSSH keys
URL formathttps://github.com/...git@github.com:...
Firewall friendly✅ Works everywhere❌ Needs port 22
2FA compatible✅ Yes✅ Yes

echo ".vscode/" >> .gitignore
echo "venv/" >> .gitignore

  2. Configure auto-crlf (line endings) for cross-OS work:

    bash

how to get PAT from github no option on site

If you can't find the Personal Access Token (PAT) creation option on GitHub, follow these steps carefully:

1. Direct Link to PAT Creation

👉 Go directly to:
https://github.com/settings/tokens/new
(This bypasses navigation issues)

2. Step-by-Step PAT Creation

A. Access Token Settings

  1. Sign in to GitHub

  2. Click your profile photo (top-right) → Settings

  3. Scroll down the left sidebar → Developer settings
    (Not visible? Try this direct link)

  4. Select Personal access tokens → Tokens (classic)
    (New "fine-grained" tokens have limited access)

B. Generate New Token

  1. Click Generate new token → Generate new token (classic)

  2. Note: Describe usage (e.g., "Flask project CLI access")

  3. Expiration: Set to 90 days (or custom)

  4. Select scopes (minimum for Git):

    • ✅ repo (Full control of private repos)

    • ✅ workflow (If using GitHub Actions)

C. Copy Token

  1. Click Generate token

  2. Immediately copy the token (you won't see it again!)

    Copy
    ghp_AbCdEfGhIjKlMnOpQrStUvWxYz12345678

3. Using the PAT

For Git HTTPS Operations

bash
Copy
git clone https://github.com/username/repo.git
Username: your_github_username
Password: ghp_your_token_here  # ← Paste the PAT

Store Credentials Securely

bash
Copy
# Cache for 1 hour
git config --global credential.helper "cache --timeout=3600"

# Or store permanently (encrypted)
git config --global credential.helper store

4. Troubleshooting

If "Developer settings" is missing

  1. Ensure you're not in an organization account

  2. Check if you have 2FA enabled (required for token creation)

For Fine-Grained Tokens (New Type)

  1. Follow the same path but select Fine-grained tokens

  2. Limitations:

    • Can't access all repos by default

    • Granular permissions per repo

5. Security Notes

  • 🔐 Never commit tokens to code

  • 🔄 Rotate tokens every 90 days

  • ❌ Revoke compromised tokens immediately at:
    https://github.com/settings/tokens

Alternative: Use GitHub CLI

bash
Copy
# Install
sudo apt install gh -y

# Authenticate
gh auth login

# Follow prompts (select HTTPS)

fatal: repository 'https://github.com/KamleshKG/skill_portal.git/' not found

This error occurs when either:

  1. The repository doesn't exist, or

  2. You don't have permission to access it.

Here's how to fix it:

1. Verify the Repository Exists

Open in browser:
👉 https://github.com/KamleshKG/skill_portal
If you see "404 Not Found", the repo doesn't exist.

2. Solutions Based on Your Goal

A. If You're Trying to Clone

bash
Copy
# Check for typos in the URL (remove trailing slash)
git clone https://github.com/KamleshKG/skill_portal.git

B. If You Own the Repo

  1. Create the repository first on GitHub:
    https://github.com/new

    • Name: skill_portal

    • Do not initialize with README/.gitignore (if pushing existing code)

  2. Then follow these commands:

bash
Copy
cd your_local_project_folder
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin https://github.com/KamleshKG/skill_portal.git
git push -u origin main

C. If It's a Private Repo

  1. Ensure you have access (ask the owner)

  2. Use a PAT (Personal Access Token) as password:

    bash
    Copy
    git clone https://github.com/KamleshKG/skill_portal.git
Username: your_github_username
Password: ghp_your_token_here  # Get PAT from GitHub settings

  1. URL Case Sensitivity:
    GitHub URLs are case-sensitive!
    KamleshKG ≠ kamleskkg

  2. HTTPS vs SSH:
    Try SSH if HTTPS fails (requires SSH keys setup):

    bash
    Copy
    git clone git@github.com:KamleshKG/skill_portal.git

  3. Network Issues:

    bash
    Copy
    ping github.com  # Check connectivity

2. Automated Daily Backups

python
Copy
# Python script to auto-archive (save as `backup_chats.py`)
import datetime
from selenium import webdriver

def save_chat():
    driver = webdriver.Chrome()
    driver.get("https://chat.openai.com/")  # Login first!
    today = datetime.datetime.now().strftime("%Y-%m-%d")
    with open(f"chat_backup_{today}.html", "w") as f:
        f.write(driver.page_source)
    driver.quit()

save_chat()

How to run:

  1. Install Python + ChromeDriver

  2. Schedule with Task Scheduler (Windows) or cron (Mac/Linux) to run daily

1. Quick Manual Save (Best for Critical Chats)

Windows/Mac:

  1. Press Ctrl + S (Windows) or Cmd + S (Mac) while the chat is open

  2. Choose "Webpage, Complete" format → Saves as .html with images/styles

  3. Organize by date:

    Copy
    /DeepSeek_Chats/
├── 2024-06-15_Flask_Help.html  
├── 2024-06-20_Corporate_Survival.html  
└── ...

Mobile Users:

  • Use browser "Share" → "Print" → "Save as PDF"

2. Automated Daily Backups (Zero Effort)

Using Python (5-minute setup):

python
Copy
# save_deepseek.py
import time
from selenium import webdriver
from datetime import datetime

def save_chat():
    driver = webdriver.Chrome()
    driver.get("https://chat.deepseek.com")  # Login first!
    time.sleep(10)  # Wait for chat load
    filename = f"DeepSeek_{datetime.now().strftime('%Y%m%d_%H%M')}.html"
    with open(filename, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
        f.write(driver.page_source)
    driver.quit()

save_chat()

Schedule it to run daily:

  • Windows: Task Scheduler

  • Mac/Linux: cron job (0 21 * * * python /path/to/save_deepseek.py)

3. Make Chats Searchable

Option A: Obsidian (Recommended)

  1. Install Obsidian

  2. Create vault → Drag/drop all .html files

  3. Install "Omnisearch" plugin → Now Ctrl+F across all chats

Option B: Local Text Search

bash
Copy
# Terminal command to search all backups:
grep -r "repository pattern" /path/to/DeepSeek_Chats/

4. Emergency Recovery

If chats disappear before backup:

  1. Browser Cache Rescue:

    bash
    Copy
    # Chrome/Edge cache location:
cd ~/Library/Caches/Google/Chrome/Default/Cache/  # Mac
cd %LOCALAPPDATA%\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Cache  # Win
strings *. | grep -A 20 -B 20 "fatal: repository"  # Find snippets

  2. Contact Support: Ask if they can provide chat history exports

5. Future-Proofing

  1. Weekly Ritual: Every Sunday, save the week's key chats

  2. Tag Important Chats: Add ⭐ to critical messages before saving

  3. Cloud Sync: Upload .html files to Google Drive/Dropbox

Your Action Plan

  1. Today: Press Ctrl+S on this chat

  2. This week: Set up the Python script

  3. Ongoing: Monthly cleanup/organization

Your knowledge stays accessible forever, even if DeepSeek's UI changes. Need help automating this? Say "Guide me through [step]" for a detailed walkthrough.

This isn't just backup—it's building your private engineering智库.

# Terminal command to compress all HTMLs (saves 70% space)
find ~/DeepSeek_Chats/ -name "*.html" -exec zip -9 chats.zip {} +

how to know default folder location

Here’s how to find the default save folder for your chat backups on any OS, plus how to change it for quicker access:

1. Find Default Save Location

Windows:

  1. Press Ctrl + S to save any file

  2. Look at the path shown in the save dialog (usually one of these):

    Copy
    C:\Users\[YourUsername]\Downloads\
C:\Users\[YourUsername]\Documents\

  3. Or check browser defaults:

    • Chrome: chrome://settings/downloads

    • Edge: edge://settings/downloads

Mac:

  1. Press Cmd + S

  2. Default is typically:

    Copy
    /Users/[YourUsername]/Downloads/

  3. Browser confirmation:

    • Safari → Preferences → General → "File download location"

Linux:

bash
Copy
# Check browser defaults (Chrome/Edge)
xdg-user-dir DOWNLOAD
# Common paths:
~/Downloads/
~/Documents/

2. Change Default Save Folder

Windows/Mac:

  1. Before saving, right-click in the save dialog → "New folder" → Name it DeepSeek_Chats

  2. Make it default:

    • Windows: Right-click folder → "Pin to Quick Access"

    • Mac: Drag folder to Finder sidebar

Browser-Specific Settings:

BrowserSteps to Change Default Folder
Chrome/Edgechrome://settings/downloads → "Change" under "Location"
Firefoxabout:preferences#general → "Save files to"

3. Pro Tip: Save Directly to Cloud

  1. Sync default folder with Dropbox/Google Drive:

    • Move DeepSeek_Chats folder to cloud sync directory

    • Now all saves auto-backup

  2. Or use symbolic links:

    bash
    Copy
    # Linux/Mac:
ln -s ~/Dropbox/DeepSeek_Chats ~/Downloads/DeepSeek_Chats
# Windows (Admin CMD):
mklink /D "C:\Users\You\Downloads\DeepSeek_Chats" "C:\Cloud\DeepSeek_Chats"

Verify Your Setup

bash
Copy
# After saving a test file:
ls ~/Downloads/DeepSeek_*.html  # Linux/Mac
dir %USERPROFILE%\Downloads\DeepSeek_*.html  # Windows

Troubleshooting

If files "disappear":

  1. Search entire system:

    • Windows: *.html in File Explorer search bar

    • Mac/Linux:

      bash
      Copy
      sudo find / -name "DeepSeek_*.html" 2>/dev/null

  2. Check browser download history (Ctrl + J)

Need me to walk you through any step? Just say "Show me [Windows/Mac/Linux] screenshots".

Your chat archive is now auto-organized! 📂

Here's how to confirm and change your default download folder across all platforms:

1. Find & Verify Default Download Folder

Windows:

  1. Quick Check:

    • Open File Explorer → Look for Downloads in left sidebar

    • Full path:

      Copy
      C:\Users\[YourUsername]\Downloads

  2. Command Line:

    cmd
    Copy
    echo %USERPROFILE%\Downloads

Mac:

  1. Quick Check:

    • Open Finder → Go menu → Downloads

    • Full path:

      Copy
      /Users/[YourUsername]/Downloads/

  2. Terminal:

    bash
    Copy
    echo ~/Downloads/

Linux:

bash
Copy
xdg-user-dir DOWNLOAD
# Typical output:
/home/[YourUsername]/Downloads

2. Change Default Download Folder (All Browsers)

Chrome/Edge:

  1. Enter in address bar:

    Copy
    chrome://settings/downloads

  2. Click Change under "Location"

  3. Select/create DeepSeek_Chats folder

Firefox:

  1. Enter:

    Copy
    about:preferences#general

  2. Under "Files and Applications", click Browse next to "Save files to"

Safari:

  1. Safari → Preferences → General

  2. Set "File download location"

3. Set Up Smart Saving

Auto-Organize Downloads (Windows/Mac)

  1. Create folder:

    Copy
    ~/Downloads/DeepSeek_Chats/

  2. Browser Extension: Install Save File to Folder

    • Rules: Auto-save .html files to DeepSeek_Chats

Terminal Users (Linux/Mac)

bash
Copy
# Watch Downloads folder, auto-move HTMLs
inotifywait -m -e moved_to ~/Downloads/ | 
while read path action file; do 
   if [[ "$file" == *".html" ]]; then 
      mv "$path$file" ~/Downloads/DeepSeek_Chats/ 
   fi 
done

4. Verify It Works

  1. Save a test chat (Ctrl + S)

  2. Check location:

    bash
    Copy
    # Linux/Mac:
ls -l ~/Downloads/DeepSeek_Chats/
# Windows:
dir "%USERPROFILE%\Downloads\DeepSeek_Chats"

Troubleshooting Missing Files

  1. Search Entire System:

    • Windows:

      cmd
      Copy
      dir /s /b "C:\DeepSeek_*.html"

    • Mac/Linux:

      bash
      Copy
      sudo find / -name "DeepSeek_*.html" 2>/dev/null

  2. Browser-Specific Recovery:

    • Chrome: chrome://downloads → Right-click → "Show in folder"

Pro Tip: Cloud Sync

bash
Copy
# Symbolic link to cloud (run once):
ln -s ~/Dropbox/DeepSeek_Chats ~/Downloads/DeepSeek_Chats

Now all saves auto-backup to cloud.
